reference.title: elementdef
reference.shortdesc: The <elementdef> element identifies an element on which an attribute is enumerated. When the <elementdef> is left out of an <enumerationdef> element, the enumeration is bound to the attribute in all elements.

section.title: Contains
section.p: The content model of this element may differ based on where it is used. Content model information is located here:

section.title: Contained By
section.p: The parents of this element may differ based on where it is used. Content model information is located here:

example.title: Example
example.p: In this example, the <lomDifficulty> element has been specialized from the <data> element. The value attribute on the <lomDifficulty> element (but not the value attribute on other elements) is bound to a specific set of values. This means that processors should limit that attribute on that element to the values veryEasy, easy, medium, difficult, or veryDifficult.
example.codeblock: <subjectScheme> <subjectdef keys="difficulty"> <subjectdef keys="veryEasy"/> <subjectdef keys="easy"/> <subjectdef keys="medium"/> <subjectdef keys="difficult"/> <subjectdef keys="veryDifficult"/> </subjectdef> ... <enumerationdef> <elementdef name="lomDifficulty"/> <attributedef name="value"/> <subjectdef keyref="difficulty"/> </enumerationdef> </subjectScheme>
